{{Infobox saint | name = Saint Abadiu | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | titles = Bishop of Antinoe | birth_date = 4th century | birth_place = [[Egypt]] | death_date = 4th century | death_place = [[Egypt]] |venerated_in =[[Coptic Orthodox Church]]
[[Eastern Orthodox Churches]]
[[Oriental Orthodox Churches]]
[[Roman Catholic Church]] | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | major_shrine = | feast_day = 26 December | attributes = | patronage = | issues = | suppressed_date = | suppressed_by = | influences = | influenced = | tradition = | major_works = }} '''Abadiu of Antinoe''' is a saint of the [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Church]]. He was the [[bishop]] of [[Antinopolis|Antinoe]], and was made a [[martyr]] by the [[Arianism|Arians]]. His [[feast day]] is December 26. He is referenced in ''[[Les Martyrs d'Égypte]]'' by [[Hippolyte Delehaye]]. ==References== *Holweck, F. G. ''A Biographical Dictionary of the Saint''. St. Louis, MO: B. Herder Book Co. 1924. {{DEFAULTSORT:Abadiu Of Antinoe}} [[Category:4th-century Christian martyrs]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:4th-century bishops]] {{Egypt-bio-stub}} {{Saint-stub}}

'''Abu Hashim al-Hasan''' (died 1040) was an [[imam]] of the [[Zaidiyyah|Zaidi]] state in [[Yemen]] who ruled part of the Yemeni highland in 1031-1040.
Abu Hashim al-Hasan was a fifth-generation descendant of al-Qasim ar-Rassi (d. 860), the theological portal figure of [[Zaydiyyah]] [[Islam]].<ref>The filiation was: al-Qasim ar-Rassi - al-Husayn - Abdallah - Yahya - Abd ar-Rahman - Abu Hashim al-Hasan.</ref> In 1031, the year after the violent death of the former imam [[al-Mu’id li-Din Illah]], he claimed the imamate.<ref>The beginning of his imamate is sometimes dated in 1027 or 1035.</ref> He was able to seize [[San'a]]. One of the local grandees, Ibn Abi Hashid, fled, while another one, Nunsur bin Abi'l-Futuh, submitted. Abu Hashim's authority in San'a lasted until 1037, when he was expelled by the tribesmen of [[Hamdan]]. The Hamdanites later invited Ja'far, brother of the old imam [[al-Mahdi al-Husayn]], to rule the city as [[emir]]. The following years were filled with contests over San'a, and Abu Hashim was able to regain control over the commercially important place for a brief term. After he had lost the city for good, he withdrew to [[Sa'dah]] in the north, which was the old stronghold of the [[Zaydiyyah]].<ref>Cesare Ansaldi, ''Il Yemen nella storia e nella leggenda''. Roma 1933, p. 134.</ref> The hard pressed Abu Hashim died in 1040. A new pretender, [[Abu'l-Fath an-Nasir ad-Dailami]], arrived from [[Persia]], possibly before Abu Hashim's death.<ref>H.C. Kay, ''Yaman; Its Early Medieval History''. London 1892, p. 229.</ref> Having proclaimed his [[da'wa]] (call for the imamate), he proceeded to seize [[Sa'dah]] and San'a some years later, in 1046.
==See also==
* [[Imams of Yemen]] * [[Rassids]]
==References==
{{Reflist}} {{start box}} {{succession box| before=[[al-Mu’id li-Din Illah]]| title=[[Imams of Yemen|Imam of Yemen]]| years=1031-1040| after=[[Abu'l-Fath an-Nasir ad-Dailami]] }} {{end box}}

page.title: Abū Jaʿfar Aḥmad ibn ʿAbd al-Malik Ibn Saʿīd

revision.comment: removed [[Category:12th-century writers]]; added [[Category:12th-century Arabic writers]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Abū Jaʿfar Aḥmad ibn ʿAbd al-Malik Ibn Saʿīd''' (died 1163) is best known as a poet, and lover of [[Hafsa Bint al-Hajj al-Rukuniyya|Ḥafṣa bint al-Ḥājj ar-Rakūniyya]] (c. 1135-1191).
==Biography== Abū Jaʿfar is said to have been taught by, amongst others, the twelfth-century poet [[Ibn Khafaja|Ibn Khafāja]]. He served as a prominent court secretary for the Almohad governor of [[Granada]], Abū Saʿid ʿUthmān. "Unfortunately for Abū Jaʿfar, his powerful boss also fell in love with Ḥafṣa, and our poet's position in the ensuing love triangle seems to have forced him to flee Granada." Joining Ibn Mardanīsh's rebellion against al-Muwaḥḥid rule in al-Andalus, Abū Jaʿfar was captured and in 1163 executed.<ref>Ross Brann, 'He Said, She Said: Reinscribing the Andalusi Arabic Love Lyric', in ''Studies in Arabic and Hebrew Letters: In Honor of Raymond P. Scheindlin'', ed. by Jonathan P. Decter and Michael Chaim Rand (Piscataway, NJ: Gorgias Press LLC, 2007), pp. 7-16 (at p. 8).</ref>
==Work== An example of Abū Jaʿfar's poetry, as translated by [[Arthur John Arberry|A. J. Arberry]], is 'Wine, my Love':<ref>''Moorish Poetry: A Translation of ’The Pennants’, an Anthology Compiled in 1243 by the Andalusian Ibn Saʿid'', trans. by A. J. Arberry (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1953), p. 100. For the original see ''El libro de las banderas de los campeones, de Ibn Saʿid al-Magribī'', ed. by Emilio García Gómez (Madrid: Instituto de Valencia de Don Juan, 1942).</ref>
:: Ho, bring her hither, happy boy, :: For in her presence is my joy, :: But (and does love need further proof?) :: I grieve when she remains aloof.
:: I speak upon the wine: when she :: Departs, the bowl weeps bitterly, :: But when the glass beholds her near :: It broadly smiles for the good cheer.
==References== {{reflist}} {{Arabic literature}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abu Jafar Ahmad ibn Abd al-Malik Ibn Said}} [[Category:Poets of Al-Andalus]] [[Category:12th-century Arabic writers]] [[Category:1163 deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]
{{Al-Andalus-writer-stub}}

page.title: Assisted suicide in the United States

revision.text:
{{mergefrom|Assisted Death in the United States|discuss=Talk:Assisted Death in the United States#Merger proposal|date=June 2018}} {{Map of legality surrounding assisted suicide in the US|align=right|size=400px}} [[Assisted suicide]] is defined as [[suicide]] committed with the aid of another person, sometimes a doctor. “Assisted suicide" has been used to describe what proponents refer to as [[medical aid in dying]] in the United States for terminally ill adults who self-administer [[barbiturates]] if they feel that they are suffering significantly. The term is often used interchangeably with physician-assisted suicide (PAS), "physician-assisted dying", "physician-assisted death", "assisted death" and "aid in dying".
Assisted suicide is similar to but distinct from euthanasia (sometimes called "mercy killing"). In cases of euthanasia another party acts to bring about the person's death in order to end ongoing suffering. In cases of assisted suicide a second person provides the means through which the individual is able to voluntarily end their own life, but they do not directly cause the individual's death.
Physician-assisted death or "aid in dying" is legal in eight jurisdictions: California, Colorado, District of Columbia, Hawaii, Montana, Oregon, Vermont, and Washington.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/feb/18/dc-physician-assisted-suicide-law-goes-effect/|title=D.C. physician-assisted suicide law goes into effect|first=The Washington Times|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|publisher=}}</ref> These laws (excluding Montana since there is no law) expressly state that, "actions taken in accordance with [the Act] shall not, for any purpose, constitute suicide, assisted suicide, mercy killing or homicide, under the law". This distinguishes the legal act of “medical aid in dying” from the act of suicide.
== History ==
===Early movements===
The first significant drive to legalize assisted suicide in the United States arose in the early years of the twentieth century. In a 2004 article in the ''[[Bulletin of the History of Medicine]]'', [[Brown University]] historian [[Jacob M. Appel]] documented extensive political debate over legislation to legalize physician-assisted death in both Iowa and Ohio in 1906. In Ohio, the legislation was inspired by the campaign of heiress [[Anna S. Hall]], whose mother had died a painful death from [[cancer]].<ref name=Appel2004>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1353/bhm.2004.0106 | last1 = Appel | first1 = JM | title = A Duty to Kill? A Duty to Die? Rethinking the Euthanasia Controversy of 1906 | journal = Bulletin of the History of Medicine | volume = 78 | issue = 3 | pages = 610–34 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15356372 | url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/bulletin_of_the_history_of_medicine/v078/78.3appel.html }}</ref> Despite Hall's efforts, the bill was rejected by the Ohio legislature by a vote of 79 to 23.<ref name=Appel2004 /><ref>{{Cite journal | date =November 1994 | pages = 793–802 | pmid = 7944057 | month = | url = http://www.annals.org/content/121/10/793.abstract | issue = 10 | volume = 121 | last1 = Emanuel | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-121-10-199411150-00010 | title = History of Euthanasia Debates in the United States and Britain | journal = Annals of Internal Medicine | first1 = E. }}</ref>
===''Glucksberg v. Washington''=== Dr. Harold Glucksberg, along with four other physicians, three terminally ill patients, and Compassion and Dying, brought a case against the state of Washington for banning assisted suicide. The case was filed in District Court in 1994.
Following a series of appeals, the U.S. Supreme Court decided in 1997 in a unanimous decision to uphold Washington's ban. They cited the Due Process Clause and argued that assisted suicide isn't guaranteed as a fundamental liberty protected by due process. The case allowed individual states to decide independently on the medical aid-in-dying issue. It set the stage for legislative efforts on the state level.
===Dr. Kevorkian=== {{main|Jack Kevorkian}} Assisted suicide in the United States was brought to public attention in the 1990s with the highly publicized case of Dr. Jack Kevorkian. Dr. Kevorkian assisted over 40 people in committing suicide in Michigan.<ref>{{Cite journal | year = 1997 | pmid = 8970940 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199701023360108| url = http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199701023360108 | pages = 50–53 | issue = 1 | first1 = M. | title = The Supreme Court and Physician-Assisted Suicide — the Ultimate Right | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 336 | last1 = Angell}}</ref> His first public assisted suicide was in 1990, of Janet Adkins, a 54-year-old woman diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer's disease in 1989. He was charged with [[murder]], but charges were dropped on December 13, 1990 because there were no Michigan laws outlawing suicide or the medical assistance of it so he was not in violation of a law.<ref>[http://www.ascensionhealth.org/ethics/public/cases/case19.asp "People v. Kevorkian; Hobbins v. Attorney General"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030908034403/http://www.ascensionhealth.org/ethics/public/cases/case19.asp |date=2003-09-08 }}. Ascension Health. 2007. Ascension Health. 7 April 2009.</ref>
Years later, Kevorkian crossed the line from assisting the patient to actively killing the patient himself. Kevorkian videotaped himself giving a man a lethal injection and aired the tape on ''[[60 Minutes]]''. He was found guilty of second-degree murder and served eight years of a 10–25 year sentence. He was released in 2007, and died on June 3, 2011.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2007/US/law/12/17/court.archive.kevorkian8/index.html "Kevorkian Case: Kevorkian sentenced to 10 to 25 years"]. [[CNN]] 31 Dec 2007 1. 7 April 2009.</ref>
===Brittany Maynard=== {{main|Brittany Maynard}} In 2014, the death of Brittany Maynard, an advocate for the legalization of [[aid in dying]], from [[brain cancer]] led to renewed debate in the United States over assisted suicide, and was cited as being responsible for bills in several states on the topic. Her home state of California, which she left to reside in Oregon to access its Death With Dignity Act, became the fifth state to authorize aid in dying, in 2015.
==Jurisdictions where assisted suicide is authorized==
===California=== {{main|California End of Life Option Act}} In 1992, the group Californians against Human Suffering proposed Proposition 161 to allow patients with less than six months to live the right to receive assistance from physicians in dying. This proposition offered more safeguards against abuse by physicians than Washington's Initiative 119, such as special protections for patients in [[nursing]] facilities. This measure failed to pass with 46 percent of the vote.<ref name="Death by Prescription">{{Cite journal| year = 1994| pmid = 7935680| doi = 10.1056/NEJM199411033311822| url = http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199411033311822| pages = 1240–1243| issue = 18 | first1 = G.| title = Death by Prescription. The Oregon Initiative| journal = The New England Journal of Medicine| volume = 331| last1 = Annas}}</ref>
Subsequent efforts were tried to pass assisted death legalization through the California State Legislature in 1999, 2005, and 2006, all of which failed. The California legislature passed the [[California End of Life Option Act]], a bill legalizing the practice in September 2015, and the bill was signed into law by [[Governor of California|Governor]] [[Jerry Brown]] on October 5, 2015, making California the fifth state to authorize [[medical aid in dying]] and the second to do so through the legislature. The Act began implementation on June 9, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/political/la-me-pc-gov-brown-end-of-life-bill-20151005-story.html|title=After struggling, Jerry Brown makes assisted suicide legal in California|first=Patrick|last=McGreevy|date=5 October 2015|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fox5sandiego.com/2015/10/05/gov-brown-signs-bill-legalizing-medically-assisted-suicide-for-terminal-patients/|title=Gov. Brown signs bill legalizing medically-assisted suicide for terminal patients|date=5 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref> The law went into effect in June 2016.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-end-of-life-option-act-qa-20160511-story.html | title=How California's aid-in-dying law will work | work=latimes.com | date=May 12, 2016 | author=Soumya Karlamangla}}</ref>
In May 2018, Judge Daniel A. Ottolia of the Superior Court of Riverside County ruled that the method of enacting the law was unconstitutional<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Wesley J. |date=16 May 2018 |title=California Assisted-Suicide Law Unconstitutionally Enacted |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/california-assisted-death-law-ruled-unconstitutional/ |work= National Review |access-date=16 May 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article211195824.html|title=California assisted death law overturned in court|last=Koseff|first=Alexei|date=2018-05-15|work=The Sacramento Bee|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en-US|issn=0890-5738}}</ref>, but the law was reinstated by a state appeals court the following month<ref>{{cite news |title=State Appeals Court Reinstates California's Right-To-Die Law |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/06/15/us/ap-us-california-assisted-death-lawsuit.html |accessdate=17 June 2018 |publisher=The New York Times |date=15 June 2018}}</ref>.
===Colorado=== Representatives [[Lois Court]] and [[Joann Ginal]] introduced assisted suicide legislation in 2015 in the Colorado House. The bill was voted down in committee 8-5.
In April 2016, Julie Selsberg and Jaren Ducker filed an initiative with the secretary of state seeking to authorize medical aid in dying in November 2016 through the ballot process.
On November 8, 2016 Colorado voters passed Proposition 106 making assisted death legal among patients with terminal illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2016/11/08/colorado-aid-in-dying-proposition-106-election-results/|title=Colorado passes medical aid in dying, joining five other states|date=8 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
===District of Columbia=== In January 2015, [[Council of the District of Columbia|D.C. Council]] member [[Mary Cheh|Mary M. Cheh]] introduced the Death with Dignity Act of 2015.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/death-with-dignity-laws-are-proposed-bringing-national-debate-to-dc-and-md/2015/01/16/8354bba8-9d09-11e4-a7ee-526210d665b4_story.html|title='Death With Dignity' laws are proposed, bringing national debate to D.C. and Md.|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|date=16 January 2015|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=16 Jan 2015}}</ref> On October 5, 2016, the D.C. Committee on Health and Human Services voted 3-2 for the Death with Dignity Act. On November 1, 2016 the D.C. Council voted 11–2 to advance the Death with Dignity Act. It then went through another vote in the council and the Mayor's office.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/oct/5/dc-weighs-physician-assisted-suicide-as-death-with/|title='Death With Dignity Act' clears first hurdle as D.C. weighs physician-assisted suicide|last=Richardson|first=Bradford|date=5 October 2016|newspaper=[[The Washington Times]]|access-date=8 October 2016}}</ref> [[Muriel Bowser|Mayor Bowser]]'s signed the bill on 23rd December, 2016. After the-30 day U.S. Congress review mandated by the federal Home Rule Act, and following the inability of Congressional Republicans to block the bill, the law went into effect on February 18, 2017, with D.C. becoming the seventh jurisdiction in the U.S. to legalize this.<ref name="auto"/>
=== Hawaii === Starting January 1, 2019 [[Hawaii]] will legally allow assisted dying, based on the Oregon and Washington state models. Governor David Ige signed a medical aid-in-dying law on April 5, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.apnews.com/91a066e44af64b538eaa7472bf6a9cb2/Medically-assisted-suicide-becomes-legal-in-Hawaii|title=Medically assisted suicide becomes legal in Hawaii|date=5 April 2018|website=apnews.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407074751/https://www.apnews.com/91a066e44af64b538eaa7472bf6a9cb2/Medically-assisted-suicide-becomes-legal-in-Hawaii|archive-date=7 April 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=5 April 2018}}</ref> The law has safeguards to protect against abuse, including two health care providers being required to confirm a patient’s diagnosis, prognosis, his or her ability to make decisions, and that the patient's request is voluntary; as well as a counselor being required to determine that the patient isn’t suffering from conditions that may interfere with decision-making, such as a lack of treatment of depression. The law requires that the patient must make two oral requests for the life-ending medication, with a 20-day waiting period in between, and sign a written request witnessed by two people, one of whom cannot be a relative. Criminal penalties applies to anyone attempting to coerce people into obtaining life-ending medication or tampering with said patient's request.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.apnews.com/91a066e44af64b538eaa7472bf6a9cb2/Medically-assisted-suicide-becomes-legal-in-Hawaii|title=Medically assisted suicide becomes legal in Hawaii|date=5 April 2018|website=apnews.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407074751/https://www.apnews.com/91a066e44af64b538eaa7472bf6a9cb2/Medically-assisted-suicide-becomes-legal-in-Hawaii|archive-date=7 April 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=5 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Montana === [[Medical aid in dying|Aid in dying]] is legal in Montana through a state supreme court decision. In ''[[Baxter v. Montana]]'' (2009) the [[Montana Supreme Court]] ruled in a 5-2 decision that state law allows for terminally ill Montanans to request lethal medication from a physician under existing statutes, in 2008. The Attorney General of the state of Montana sought an appeal from the Montana Supreme Court, but the court, by a decision of five to two, affirmed the lower court's ruling on the state law. The Court did, however, limit the scope of the decision by not determining if the state's constitution protected the right.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/dec/31/montana-high-court-state-allows-assisted-suicide/ |title=Mont. court: State law doesn't prevent assisted suicide |publisher=''[[The Spokesman-Review]]'' |date=2009-12-31 |accessdate=2009-12-31| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100103092317/http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2009/dec/31/montana-high-court-state-allows-assisted-suicide/| archivedate= 3 January 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Oregon=== {{main|Oregon Ballot Measure 16 (1994)}} Oregon voters first approved the [[Oregon Ballot Measure 16 (1994)|Death with Dignity Act]] (DWDA) by general election in November 1994 by a margin of 51% to 49%. Ballot Measure 16, a citizen initiative sponsored by Oregon Right to Die Political Action Committee,<ref>[https://www.questia.com/googleScholar.qst?docId=5002204824 "Oregon's Fight over the Right to Die"]. Courtney S. Campbell; The Hastings Center Report, Vol. 24, 1994.</ref> asked if terminally ill patients with less than 6 months to live should be able to receive a [[Medical prescription|prescription]] for lethal drugs and included many provisions to protect against misuse, such as two oral requests and a written request from the patient. The patient must also be referred to [[counseling]] if a mental illness is suspected.
The law went into effect in October 1997 after an injunction delayed implementation. In November 1997, Measure 51 was placed on the general election ballot to repeal the Act. Voters chose to retain the Act by a margin of 60% to 40%.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oregon.gov/oha/ph/ProviderPartnerResources/EvaluationResearch/DeathwithDignityAct/Pages/index.aspx | title=Death with Dignity Act}}</ref> Since the law has been in effect, it has given Oregon residents and patients a full range of options when dealing with their illness. This law has allowed for patients to consult their doctors about this option (about 1 in 50), while then at least 1 in 6 patients go on to talk to their families about the matter (Quill & Sussman, n.d.) URL:https://www.thehastingscenter.org/briefingbook/physician-assisted-death/. The law gives patients a full range of options when ultimately deciding the best route to help make their lives comfortable when coping with this illness.
====Challenges====
=====''Lee v. State of Oregon''===== In December 1994, doctors and patients argued that the DWDA violated the U.S. Constitution's first and fourteenth amendments in ''Lee v. Oregon''. U.S. District Court Judge Michael Hogan placed a temporary injunction, that he later made permanent, on the Act.
In February 1997, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled to dismiss the challenge to the Death with Dignity Act.
=====Measure 51, Oregon Repeal of Death with Dignity ===== In 1997, Measure 51 was placed on the November ballot. It failed and 60% of Oregon voters, more than the original 1994 vote, expressed their support for the Death with Dignity Act.
=====''Oregon v. Ashcroft''===== U.S. Attorney General John Ashcroft issued a directive in 2001 to prevent the Oregon Death With Dignity Act from being implemented. The state of Oregon successfully sued and proceeded with implementation.<ref>https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=1750729 3978677110948&hl=en&as_sdt=6&as_vis=1&oi=scholarr 11Oregon v.s Ashcoft, 368 F.3d 1118 (2004) https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=6864220915455 147792&hl=en&as_sdt=6,38</ref>
===Vermont=== In May 2013, the [[Vermont Legislature]] passed the Patient Choice and Control at End of Life Act. Governor [[Peter Shumlin]] signed it into law. The law is based on, but is less restrictive than, the Oregon model.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/05/14/vermont-physician-assisted-death-bill/2157333/ |title=Vermont end-of-life bill heads to governor |first=Terri |last=Hallenbeck |location=[[Burlington, Vermont]] |newspaper=USA Today |date=May 14, 2013 |accessdate=May 14, 2013}}</ref>
Vermont was the first state to pass an aid in dying law through the legislative process. In January 2013 the act was introduced to the Senate, and in May 2013 it was passed by both the house and senate.
Vermont residents 18 years old or older who are mentally capable adults with a terminal illness and a prognosis of 6 months or less to live can make an oral request and obtain medication from a physician. The bill requires a second opinion, written and oral requests, and other provisions. <ref name=bfp130714>{{Cite news | first=Terri | last=Hallenbeck | title=Vermont adjusts to new way of dying | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/07/14/vermont-adjusts-to-new-way-of-dying/2514847/| work= | newspaper=[[The Burlington Free Press]] | location=[[Burlington, Vermont]] | pages= 6B-9B | date=July 14, 2013 | id= | accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref><!---hard and soft copy sources differ. They are identical articles--->
===Washington=== In 1991, a ballot question asked if terminally ill adults should be allowed to receive physician aid-in-dying. The initiative failed, receiving 46 percent of the vote.<ref name="Death by Prescription" />
Washington voters approved the [[Washington Death with Dignity Act|Death with Dignity Act]] by general election in November 2008 by a margin of 58% to 42% "This measure would permit terminally ill, competent, adult Washington residents medically predicted to die within six months to request and self-administer lethal medication prescribed by a physician. The measure requires two oral and one written request, two physicians to diagnose the patient and determine the patient is competent, a waiting period, and physician verification of an informed patient decision. Physicians, patients and others acting in good faith compliance would have criminal and civil immunity."<ref>[http://www.secstate.wa.gov/elections/initiatives/text/i1000.pdf The Washington Death with Dignity Act]</ref>
==Other jurisdictions==
===Alaska=== In 1999, two terminally ill patients, Kevin Sampson and Jane Doe, sued for an order to exempt their physicians from being charged with manslaughter for assisting them in dying. The superior court ruled against them, and they appealed to the Alaska Supreme Court. This court upheld the previous ruling with the reasoning that the Alaska Constitution's right to privacy and liberty does not allow terminally ill patients to be assisted by physicians in dying.<ref name=marker/>
===Arizona=== In Arizona, the city of [[Bisbee, Arizona|Bisbee]] became the first municipality in the state to approve an aid in dying resolution, although the vote is not legally binding.
The resolution states that the city of Bisbee: * Respects the diversity of perspectives of its citizens, * Supports equal protection within the diversity of perspectives on end-of-life decisions, * Recognizes the practice of Aid in Dying as a legitimate individual liberty, * And, while not a legally enforceable document, urges prosecutorial discretion by the Cochise County Attorney in de-prioritizing cases involving prosecution of a person who has supported, been present, or facilitated a loved one to advance the time of his or her imminent death when facing intolerable suffering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tucsonweekly.com/TheRange/archives/2015/09/02/bisbee-becomes-first-city-in-arizona-to-approve-an-aid-in-dying-resolution|title=Bisbee Becomes First City in Arizona to Approve an 'Aid in Dying' Resolution|first=María Inés|last=Taracena|publisher=}}</ref>
===Connecticut=== Legislation to legalize assisted suicide received a public hearing by Connecticut's state legislature for three consecutive sessions in 2013, 2014, and 2015, but has failed to receive a committee vote. State representative Jonathan Steinberg introduced HB 6024, An Act Concerning Aid in Dying for Terminally Ill Patients, on January 19, 2017, with Representative Josh Elliott (D-88th District) co-sponsoring. The bill was referred to the Joint Committee on Public Health.<ref>{{cite news|date=9 April 2015|title=Aid-in-dying bill hasn't gained sufficient support|url=http://www.ctpost.com/local/article/For-3rd-time-aid-in-dying-bill-lacked-support-6190026.php|newspaper=[[Connecticut Post]]|access-date=2 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cga.ct.gov/asp/cgabillstatus/cgabillstatus.asp?selBillType=Bill&bill_num=HB06024&which_year=2017|title=Connecticut General Assembly|website=Connecticut General Assembly}}</ref>
===Florida=== ''Krischer v. McIver'' was a case brought to the Florida Supreme Court in 1997 by the Florida chapter of the Hemlock Society in an attempt to overturn the state's anti-assisted suicide law. The question was if AIDS patient Charles Hall had this right, and the case was appealed to the Florida Supreme Court. This court upheld the constitutionality of Florida's law against assisted suicide.<ref name=marker>Marker, Rita L. (2009). "[http://www.patientsrightscouncil.org/site/assisted-suicide-the-continuing-debate/#45 Assisted Suicide: The Continuing Debate]". International Task Force 1-18. 1 March 2009.</ref>
===Maryland=== In early 2015 Maryland lawmakers began debating a "Death With Dignity" bill, though governor [[Larry Hogan]] had suggested he would oppose it.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wiggins|first=Ovetta|date=6 March 2015|title=Maryland weighs 'Death With Dignity' legislation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/md-politics/maryland-weighs-death-with-dignity-legislation/2015/03/06/187fa3b6-c3a0-11e4-9ec2-b418f57a4a99_story.html|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=1 April 2015}}</ref>
===Massachusetts=== [[File:Physician-assisted suicide (Question 2) Massachusetts 2012 ballot measure voting results by municipality.svg|thumb|300px|Voting results for the 2012 [[Massachusetts Death with Dignity Initiative]]]] The [[Massachusetts Death with Dignity Initiative]], a ballot measure to legalize aid in dying, was narrowly defeated in the [[Massachusetts general election, 2012|2012 general election]], with 51% of voters against the proposal.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
A poll taken by the Boston Globe and the University of New Hampshire between September 21 and September 27, 2012, found Massachusetts residents supporting Question 2 68%, with 20% opposed. Another public poll by the University of Massachusetts and YouGov American found similar results as late as October 8 with 65% in support and 19% opposed.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
===New Jersey=== A [[New Jersey]] Assembly committee voted in favor of assisted suicide legislation, and the full state Assembly plans to vote on Assemblyman John Burzichelli's bill, known as A 2270, the New Jersey Death with Dignity Act,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2014/Bills/A2500/2270_I1.HTM|title=A2270|website=www.njleg.state.nj.us}}</ref> on November 13, 2014, although the bill failed to receive a vote in the Senate. The bill would have required patients suffering from a terminal disease to first verbally request a prescription from their attending physician, followed by a second verbal request at least 15 days later and one request in writing signed by two witnesses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.app.com/story/news/politics/capitolquickies/2014/06/05/assisted-suicide-bill-advances-in-new-jersey-assembly/10020099/|title=Assisted suicide bill advances in New Jersey Assembly|publisher=}}</ref> In addition, the attending physician would have to offer the patient a chance to rescind their request. Governor [[Chris Christie]], at the time the bill was going through a legislative review and voting, vowed to veto any bills related to allowing assisted suicide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Malo|first1=Sebastien|title=New Jersey state Assembly approves assisted suicide bill|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/11/14/us-usa-newjersey-assistedsuicide-idUSKCN0IY01Z20141114|accessdate=13 November 2014|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=13 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Ford|first=Andrew|date=4 March 2015|title=N.J. conflicted on aid in dying|url=http://www.courierpostonline.com/story/news/local/new-jersey/2015/03/03/new-jersey-fighting-die-christie-mum/24330561/|newspaper=[[Courier-Post]]|access-date=1 April 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/10/aid_in_dying_legislation_for_terminally_ill_assemb.html]</ref> Recently, the State Senator, Nicolas Scutar, has recently introduced the Aid in Dying for the Terminally Ill Act in January 2018.<ref>[http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/2018/Bills/S1500/1072_I1.PDF]</ref> It is unknown if Governor [[Phil Murphy]] plans to support or veto any bills that may allow assisted suicides in New Jersey.
===New Mexico=== A New Mexico court legalized the practice in Bernalillo County in January 2014; this decision was overturned on August 11, 2015, which upheld the state's ban on assisted suicide.<ref name="NM">{{cite news |date=11 August 2015|title=New Mexico Court of Appeals strikes down ruling that essentially allowed assisted suicides\url=http://www.lcsun-news.com/las_cruces-news/ci_28623731/new-mexico-court-appeals-strikes-down-right-die|newspaper=Las Cruces Sun-News}}</ref>
===New York=== In 1994, a suit was filed in New York claiming that the anti-assisted suicide statute was a violation of equal protection and liberty guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment. This claim was rejected by the District Court on the basis that there is no right to assisted suicide given by the U.S. Constitution. In 1996, the [[U.S. Court of Appeals]] overturned this ruling with the reasoning that the criminalization of assisted suicide violates the Equal Protection Clause. However, the U.S. Supreme Court unanimously reversed the U.S. Court of Appeals decision in ''[[Vacco v. Quill]],'' 521 U.S. 793 (1997).
In February 2015, New York state senators [[Brad Hoylman]] and [[Diane Savino]] introduced a "Death With Dignity Act" to allow physician-assisted suicide in the state.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lovett|first=Kenneth|date=9 February 2015|title=Timothy Cardinal Dolan will fight efforts in New York to legalize physician-assisted suicide|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/timothy-cardinal-dolan-fight-bill-assisted-suicide-article-1.2107898|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)]]|access-date=1 Apr 2015}}</ref>
On September 7, 2017, in ''Myers v. Schneiderman'', the New York Court of Appeals held that terminally-ill persons did not possess a right to physician-assisted suicide under the New York State Constitution.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2017/09/07/court-of-appeals-rejects-right-to-aid-in-dying-114347|title= |last= Niedzwiadek|first= Nick|date= September 7, 2017|website= www.politico.com|publisher= |access-date= October 29, 2017|quote=}}</ref>
===Nevada=== In May 2017, a bill was passed by the [[Nevada Senate|state senate]], which sought to legalize physician-assisted suicide. The Nevada Assembly Committee on Health and Human Services chose not to advance the bill in the 2017 season. Supporters say that they intend to reintroduce the legislation at Nevada's next legislative session, which will not take place until 2019. <ref>{{cite news |last=Richardson|first=Seth |date=23 May 2017|title=Senate passes bill permitting doctor-assisted suicide|url=http://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2017/05/23/senate-passes-bill-permitting-doctor-assisted-suicide/340294001/|work=Reno Gazette Journal|location= |access-date=26 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://freebeacon.com/issues/nv-assisted-suicide-bill-dead-committee/|title=NV Assisted Suicide Bill Dead in Committee: Becomes 16th state to reject legislation in 2017|date=2017-06-07|work=Washington Free Beacon|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Tennessee=== [[Tennessee]]'s legislature debated legalizing assisted suicide in 2015.<ref name=TennesseeJoins>{{cite news|last1=Boucher|first1=Dave|title=Tennessee joins national debate on assisted suicide|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2015/06/08/changing-law-end-life/28711247/|accessdate=15 June 2015|work=[[The Tennessean]]|date=8 June 2015}}</ref>
==State power to allow and regulate==
States have the power to regulate, allow or prohibit assisted suicide.
In 1997, in the cases of ''[[Washington v. Glucksberg]]'' and ''[[Vacco v. Quill]]'', the U.S. Supreme Court ruled unanimously that there is no Constitutional right to assisted suicide, and that states therefore have the right to prohibit it. Advocates of assisted suicide saw this as opening the door for debate on the issue at the state level.<ref name=marker/>
''[[Gonzales v. Oregon]]'' was brought to the United States [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] in 2006. The court ruled that the United States Attorney General could not enforce the federal Controlled Substances Act against physicians who prescribed drugs, in compliance with Oregon state law, for the assisted suicide of the terminally ill.

{{featured article}} {{Use American English|date=May 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox television episode | title = Barge of the Dead | caption = Aboard the Barge of the Dead | series = [[Star Trek: Voyager]] | season = 6 | episode = 3 | production = 223 | airdate = {{Start date|1999|10|06}} | teleplay = [[Bryan Fuller]] | story = [[Ronald D. Moore]]
[[Bryan Fuller]] | director = [[Mike Vejar]] | music = [[David Bell (composer)|David Bell]] | guests = * [[Eric Pierpoint]] as Kortar * [[Sherman Augustus]] as Hij'Qa * [[Karen Austin]] as Miral | prev = [[Survival Instinct (Star Trek: Voyager)|Survival Instinct]] | next = [[Tinker, Tenor, Doctor, Spy]] | season_article = Star Trek: Voyager (season 6) | episode_list = List of Star Trek: Voyager episodes }} "'''Barge of the Dead'''" is an episode of the American [[science fiction on television|science fiction television]] series ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]''. It is the third episode of the [[List of Star Trek: Voyager episodes|sixth season]] and was first broadcast by [[UPN]] on October 6, 1999. "Barge of the Dead" was developed from a story by [[Ronald D. Moore]] and [[Bryan Fuller]], who wrote the teleplay, and was directed by [[Mike Vejar]]. Set in the 24th century, the series follows the adventures of the [[Starfleet]] and [[Maquis (Star Trek)|Maquis]] crew of the starship [[USS Voyager (Star Trek)|USS ''Voyager'']] after they are stranded in the [[Delta Quadrant]], far from the rest of the [[United Federation of Planets|Federation]]. In this episode, the half-[[Klingon]], half-human [[B'Elanna Torres]] ([[Roxann Dawson]]) has a [[near-death experience]] and is sent to the Klingon version of [[Hell]] known as [[Gre'Thor|Gre'thor]]. There she encounters her Klingon mother Miral ([[Karen Austin]]), who is damned because of Torres' refusal to fully accept her own identity as a Klingon. After being resuscitated by the ''Voyager'' crew, Torres becomes intent on revisiting Gre'thor to save her mother. The episode also guest stars [[Eric Pierpoint]] as [[Kortar]], who ferries the souls of the dishonored on the Barge of the Dead, and Sherman Augustus as the dead Klingon Hij'Qa. Moore originally developed the episode as part of a pitch for the ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' episode "[[Soldiers of the Empire]]". The idea was initially rejected, but was revisited for ''Star Trek: Voyager''. Following the episode's completion, both Moore and Fuller left the series because of dissatisfaction with their lack of control over its direction, and the perceived absence of strong story arcs across multiple episodes. "Barge of the Dead" was one of several episodes that addressed Torres' strained relationship with her parents and her Klingon heritage. Scholars have offered a range of opinions on Gre'thor, with the setting and ideology compared to [[Norse mythology]], [[Greek mythology]], and [[Catholic theology]]. The episode received a [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen rating]] of 3.8/6 ratings share, meaning 3.8 percent of all households with a television viewed it and six percent of that number were actively watching it. It was a drop from the episode broadcast the previous week. Critical response to the episode was mixed; some [[television criticism|television critics]] praised the focus on Torres and Dawson's performance, while others were critical of the representation of Klingon spirituality. ==Plot== While returning from an [[Away team (Star Trek term)|away mission]], [[B'Elanna Torres]] encounters interference from an [[Geomagnetic storm|ion storm]] which results in a [[concussion]]. Commander [[Chakotay]] finds a [[Klingon]] artifact lodged inside Torres' [[Shuttlecraft (Star Trek)|shuttlecraft]], and Torres sees this emitting blood and hears voices speaking in the [[Klingon language]]. Since the [[USS Voyager (Star Trek)|USS ''Voyager'']] has been stranded in the [[Delta Quadrant]], the crew is several thousand [[light-year]]s away from Klingon-controlled space. [[Morale]] officer [[Neelix]] plans a celebration of the discovery of the object, believing it originates from the [[Alpha Quadrant]] and thus proves that the USS ''Voyager'' is getting closer to home; Torres resists the proposal for a party. She consults with Security Chief [[Tuvok]], who believes her negative response to the object stems from her hatred of her Klingon heritage. Tuvok assaults Torres with a Klingon weapon called a [[bat'leth]], saying she is not a true Klingon before dismissing her as dishonored. While attending the festivities in the mess hall, Torres notices [[The Doctor (Star Trek: Voyager)|the Doctor]] and [[Seven of Nine]] singing Klingon drinking songs and [[Tom Paris]] eating Klingon cuisine. After witnessing several Klingon warriors killing the crew, she falls and finds herself aboard a boat. Torres discovers that she is being transported to [[Gre'Thor|Gre'thor]] on the Barge of the Dead, and learns that her mother Miral was placed aboard as a dishonored soul. Torres, who was in a [[coma]] the entire time, is resuscitated by Paris and the Doctor; she had almost died from the accident in the ion storm. Chakotay believes that Torres' encounter with her mother was a hallucination prompted from her [[near-death experience]], but she believes that it was real. Torres believes that her mother is being punished because of her daughter's dishonor, stating that she must return to the Barge of the Dead to rescue her. Captain [[Kathryn Janeway]] permits Torres to put herself in an [[induced coma]], with the Doctor monitoring the procedure. After being placed in a coma, Torres successfully returns to the barge. She reunites with her mother, but they argue about whether or not she has truly embraced Klingon spirituality. Miral responds by telling her that she does not understand what it truly means to be a Klingon. After their conversation, Torres decides to take her mother's place on the barge; even though Miral resists the transference, she is allowed to move on [[Sto-vo-kor]] (a version of the [[afterlife]] similar to the [[Norse mythology|Norse]] [[Valhalla]]) while Torres is escorted into Gre'thor. She discovers that ''Voyager'' is her version of Gre'thor, and is confronted by alternate versions of the crew. Miral returns to explain that she cannot fully be released into Sto-vo-kor until Torres completes her journey. Tuvok attacks Torres again with a bat'leth, but she surrenders rather than fighting back. Miral identifies this as the first step in her path. She informs Torres that they will reunite either in Sto-vo-kor or when Torres returns home. Torres is resuscitated and embraced by Janeway. ==Production== [[File:Ronald D Moore - Comic Con 2013.jpg|thumb|alt=A man with shoulder length hair is looking towards the camera.|[[Ronald D. Moore]] originally pitched the idea for "Barge of the Dead" as a ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' episode before it was produced for ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]''.]] The 43-minute, 56-second episode{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/star-trek-voyager-season-6/id458910724|title=Star Trek: Voyager, Season 6|dead-url=no|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519145016/https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/star-trek-voyager-season-6/id458910724|archivedate=May 19, 2017}} was developed from a story by [[Ronald D. Moore]] and [[Bryan Fuller]], who wrote the teleplay, and was directed by [[Mike Vejar]].[[#ruditis2003|Ruditis (2003)]]: p. 325. David Bell edited the music, and Richard D. James was the production designer.{{cite episode|title=Barge of the Dead|series=[[Star Trek: Voyager]]|network=[[UPN]]|season=6|credits=Teleplay: Bryan Fuller Story: Ronald D. Moore & Bryan Fuller. Director: Mike Vejar|airdate=October 6, 1999}} The concept for the episode developed from Moore's failed pitch for the ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' episode "[[Soldiers of the Empire]]", which would have seen the Klingon [[starship]] ''Rotarran'' travel to Gre'thor. Moore's idea was rejected as "too philosophical for this late in the [[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine (season 5)|season]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.tor.com/2014/07/15/star-trek-deep-space-nine-rewatch-soldiers-of-the-empire/|title=Star Trek: Deep Space Nine Rewatch: "Soldiers of the Empire"|last=DeCandido|first=Keith|date=July 15, 2014|work=[[Tor.com]]|publisher=[[Tor Books]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519191131/http://www.tor.com/2014/07/15/star-trek-deep-space-nine-rewatch-soldiers-of-the-empire/|archivedate=May 19, 2017|deadurl=no}} The barge would later appear in ''[[Star Trek Online]]'', a [[massively multiplayer online role-playing game]] (MMORPG) developed by [[Cryptic Studios]] based on the ''[[Star Trek]]'' franchise.[[#Bainbridge2013|Bainbridge (2013)]]: pp. 52-53. Moore only contributed to two episodes in ''Star Trek: Voyager'', with the other being "[[Survival Instinct (Star Trek: Voyager)|Survival Instinct]]", the immediate predecessor to "Barge of the Dead". Discussing why he left the series, he said that he wanted to further develop more of its story arcs and characters, particularly focusing on the "internal strife among people trapped aboard ship(s) without any reasonable hope of finding sanctuary anytime soon".[[#PankCaro2009|Pank & Caro (2009)]]: p. 200. Fuller also left ''Star Trek: Voyager'' after the completion of the episode, citing disappointment in his lack of control over the show's direction.{{cite web|url=http://www.blastr.com/2016-2-29/every-bryan-fuller-star-trek-episode-ranked|title=Every Bryan Fuller Star Trek episode, ranked|last=Roth|first=Dany|date=February 29, 2016|publisher=[[Blastr]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519142346/http://www.blastr.com/2016-2-29/every-bryan-fuller-star-trek-episode-ranked|archivedate=May 19, 2017|deadurl=no}} He said that he "began to get itchy and wanting to tell stories with a little more emotional depth", and that he disliked how [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] discouraged longer story arcs spanning multiple episodes. Fuller's episodes frequently focused on "character development through adversity". [[ExtremeTech]]'s Joel Hruska wrote that the show's later seasons would typically feature Seven of Nine, the Doctor, and Janeway to the detriment of the rest of the cast, while Fuller would draw more attention to the more underused characters.{{cite web|url=https://www.extremetech.com/gaming/222755-bryan-fuller-to-helm-new-star-trek-series-what-do-his-past-episodes-tell-us-about-the-new-show|title=Bryan Fuller to helm new Star Trek series: What do his past episodes tell us about the new show?|last=Hruska|first=Joel|date=February 10, 2016|publisher=[[ExtremeTech]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519143724/https://www.extremetech.com/gaming/222755-bryan-fuller-to-helm-new-star-trek-series-what-do-his-past-episodes-tell-us-about-the-new-show|archivedate=May 19, 2017 |deadurl=no}} While discussing the episode, actress [[Roxann Dawson]] described the storyline as a "classic Star Trek story" due to its focus on family.{{cite web|url=http://titanmagazines.com/t/star-trek/features/interviews/interview-roxann-dawson/|title=An interview with Roxann Dawson|date=December 22, 2010|publisher=[[Titan Magazines]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308041427/http://titanmagazines.com/t/star-trek/features/interviews/interview-roxann-dawson/|archivedate=March 8, 2013 |deadurl=no}} The episode features [[Karen Austin]] as Torres' mother Miral, and also includes [[Eric Pierpoint]] as [[Kortar]], who ferries the souls of the dishonored on the Barge of the Dead, and Sherman Augustus as the dead Klingon Hij'Qa. == Analysis == [[File:Otto Brausewetter Die Barke des Charon.jpg|left|thumb|alt=A painting of a man guiding a group of people on a boat through a river.|Critics compared the episode's representation of Gre'thor to mythological views of the afterlife, such as the rainbow bridge [[Bifröst]] or the river [[Styx]] (''pictured'').]] [[TrekNation|''TrekToday'']]'s Edward James Hines identified "Barge of the Dead" as the final part of a "probably unplanned 'Torres Trilogy'", which also included the episodes "[[Day of Honor]]" and "[[Extreme Risk (Star Trek: Voyager)|Extreme Risk]]". Each one was broadcast as the third episode of their respective seasons; Hines viewed each installment of the trilogy as being linked by Torres' fear of death. He wrote that the episode showed how Torres becomes "responsible to herself and to others - no matter the risk - while choosing to live".{{cite web|url=https://www.trektoday.com/reviews/barge_of_the_dead.shtml|title=Barge of the Dead|last=Hines|first=Edward James|date=October 6, 1999|website=[[TrekNation|TrekToday]]|publisher=Christian Höhne Sparborth |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170522023623/https://www.trektoday.com/reviews/barge_of_the_dead.shtml|archivedate=May 22, 2017 |deadurl=no}} Writer [[Paul Ruditis]] viewed the emphasis on Torres' "duality of nature" as leading to the development of several episodes prominently showcasing her character, including "Barge of the Dead".[[Barge of the Dead#ruditis2003|Ruditis (2003)]]: p. 7. Ruditis connected Torres' storyline to Seven of Nine's in "Survival Instinct", writing that they both "deal with issues of life and death, with dramatic results". He referred to "Barge of the Dead" and "Survival Instinct" as "equally dark episodes".[[Barge of the Dead#ruditis2003|Ruditis (2003)]]: p. 319. "Barge of the Dead" was also one of three episodes that featured Torres' relationship with her parents, with the [[Star Trek: Voyager (season 7)|season seven]] episodes "[[Lineage (Star Trek: Voyager)|Lineage]]" and "[[Author, Author (Star Trek: Voyager)|Author, Author]]" resolving her estrangement from her father.[[#ruditis2003|Ruditis (2003)]]: p. 315. "Barge of the Dead" was the first episode to provide a detailed account of Gre'thor, which was previously referenced only in ''Star Trek: The Next Generation''. The title was developed from "the Klingon belief that the dead travel to Gre'thor on a barge steered by a ferryman". [[Religious studies]] scholars Ross Kraemer, William Cassidy, and Susan L Schwartz interpreted the representation of Gre'thor and Klingon spirituality as borrowing from Norse and [[Greek mythology|Greek]] mythology, specifically the crossing of the rainbow bridge [[Bifröst]] or the river [[Styx]].[[#KraemerCassidySchwartz2009|Kraemer, Cassidy, & Schwartz (2009)]] Exploring the influence of the Greek story of [[Odysseus]] (Latin: Ulysses) on ''Star Trek: Voyager'', the [[Classical philologist]] [[Otta Wenskus]] points to [[Siren (mythology)|Siren]]-like creatures who call out with the voices of those loved by those on the barge. Though the motif of a barge and ferryman is not present in [[Homer]]'s portrayal of the underworld in the ''[[Odyssey]]'', it was subsequently popularized by its use in [[Virgil]]'s ''[[Aeneid]]'' and [[Dante]]'s ''[[Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]''.[[#Wenskus2017|Wenskus (2017)]]: p. 455. The pediatrician Victor Grech, in a paper on Klingon culture, interpreted Torres' belief in the Klingon mythological figure [[Fek'lhr]], who tortures the souls of the dishonored, as being in line with [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] views of [[Satan]].[[#Grech2016|Grech (2016)]]: p. 81. Kraemer, Cassidy, and Schwartz argued that "Barge of the Dead" mirrored the ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' [[Star Trek: The Next Generation (season 6)|season six]] episode "[[Rightful Heir]]" by not providing a clear answer whether Torres' experiences in the Klingon afterlife were real or part of a hallucination. The [[Native American studies]] scholar Sierra S. Adare was critical of the portrayal of Chakotay—a Native American character—as dismissive of Torres' sincere belief in her experiences, writing that "[n]o Native person would ever dismiss another's visions as hallucinations or tell them to ignore their religious beliefs". She cited it as one instance in which the series represented Chakotay as "the quintessential [[Tonto]] in outer space".[[#Adare2009|Adare (2009)]]: p. 95. ==Broadcast history and release== "Barge of the Dead" was first broadcast on October 6, 1999, on [[UPN]] at 8:00 pm [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Standard Time]] in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/star-trek-voyager/episode-3-season-6/barge-of-the-dead/100412/|title=Season 6, Episode 3 Barge of the Dead|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[TV Guide]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519151500/http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/star-trek-voyager/episode-3-season-6/barge-of-the-dead/100412/|archivedate=May 19, 2017 |deadurl=no}}[[#brooksmarsh2009|Brooks & Marsh (2009)]]: p. 973. The episode received a [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen rating]] of 3.8/6 ratings share. This means 3.8 percent of all households with a television viewed the episode, while among those households watching TV during this time period six percent of them were actively watching the program.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings.aspx?id=ratings_faq|title=Frequently Asked Questions About Nielsen Ratings|date=September 19, 2010|publisher=[[The Futon Critic]]|accessdate=August 23, 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170905133327/http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings.aspx?id=ratings_faq|archivedate=September 5, 2017|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}} "Barge of the Dead" placed in 93rd place overall for the week. This marked a drop in viewership compared to the previous episode, "Survival Instinct", which had earned a 3.9 rating.{{cite news|url=http://users.telenet.be/WebTrek/Voy/Ratings/ratings.html |title=Nielsen Ratings: Season 6 |publisher=Users.telenet.be |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140821182015/http://users.telenet.be/WebTrek/Voy/Ratings/ratings.html |archivedate=August 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The episode was first released for home media use on [[VHS]] in the United Kingdom, as part of a two-episode collection with "[[Tinker, Tenor, Doctor, Spy]]".{{cite web|title=Star Trek Voyager - Vol. 6.2 (Barge of the Dead/Tinker,Tenor,Doctor, Spy) [VHS] |url=https://www.amazon.com/Star-Trek-Voyager-Tinker-Doctor/dp/B00004RCQ6|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |archivedate=May 19, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519183336/https://www.amazon.com/Star-Trek-Voyager-Tinker-Doctor/dp/B00004RCQ6 |deadurl=no |df= }} It was released on [[DVD]] as part of the sixth season on December 7, 2004.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Star-Trek-Voyager-Complete-Season/dp/B00062IDLA/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1495219094&sr=8-2&keywords=voyager+season+6 |title=Star Trek Voyager - The Complete Sixth Season |publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |archivedate=May 19, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519183852/https://www.amazon.com/Star-Trek-Voyager-Complete-Season/dp/B00062IDLA/ref%3Dsr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1495219094&sr=8-2&keywords=voyager%2Bseason%2B6 |deadurl=no |df= }} It was the only ''Star Trek: Voyager'' episode included on the DVD compilation ''Star Trek Fan Collective - Klingon'', which was released on August 1, 2006. The episode has also been made available on numerous [[Media streaming|streaming]] [[video on demand]] services, such as [[Amazon Video]],{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/video/detail/B0171665UY?ref_=aiv_dp_season_select|title=Star Trek: Voyager Season 6|publisher=[[Amazon Video]]|archivedate=May 19, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519184643/https://www.amazon.com/gp/video/detail/B0171665UY?ref_=aiv_dp_season_select|deadurl=no|df=}} [[iTunes]], [[Hulu]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/star-trek-voyager|title=Star Trek: Voyager, Season 1|publisher=[[Hulu]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://www.hulu.com/star-trek-voyager|archivedate=September 26, 2016}} and [[Netflix]].{{cite web|url=https://www.netflix.com/title/70158331|title=Star Trek: Voyager|publisher=[[Netflix]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170420003124/https://www.netflix.com/nl/title/70158331|archivedate=April 20, 2017|df=}} ==Critical reception== [[File:Roxann Dawson (cropped).JPG|thumb|[[Roxann Dawson]], pictured in 2003, was praised for her performance.|alt=A woman with short brown hair and a red top is smiling toward the camera.]] [[Television criticism|Television critics]] responded positively to Dawson's performance and the episode's focus on Torres. ''[[IGN]]''{{'s}} Peter Schorn wrote that the episode was "[a]nchored by Dawson's panicked performance", and praised the focus on the character's internal conflict.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/08/02/star-trek-klingon-fan-collective|title=Star Trek: Klingon (Fan Collective)|last=Schorn|first=Peter|date=August 1, 2006|work=[[IGN]]|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170905134422/http://www.ign.com/articles/2006/08/02/star-trek-klingon-fan-collective|archivedate=September 5, 2017|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}} While reviewing the episode as a part of the "Torres Trilogy", Edward James Hines praised it as "impressively manag[ing] to weave an evolving story of personal exploration"; he wrote that all of the episodes involved in the trilogy left a "legacy of imaginative, gut-wrenching storytelling". The episode's representation of Klingon mythology garnered negative reviews from critics. ''TrekToday''{{'s}} Michelle Erica Green responded positively to the performances by Dawson, [[Tim Russ]], and [[Kate Mulgrew]], but felt that the storyline bore too many similarities to those from earlier ''[[Star Trek]]'' installments and the 1990 film ''[[Flatliners]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.trektoday.com/reviews/voy/barge_of_the_dead.shtml|title=Barge of the Dead|last=Green|first=Michelle Erica|date=January 13, 2004|website=[[TrekNation|TrekToday]]|publisher=Christian Höhne Sparborth|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519141606/https://www.trektoday.com/reviews/voy/barge_of_the_dead.shtml|archivedate=May 19, 2017 |deadurl=no}} Hines, of the same publication, was disappointed by the absence of Fek'lhr, who had been introduced in the ''Star Trek: The Next Generation'' episode "[[Devil's Due (Star Trek: The Next Generation)|Devil's Due]]", and wrote that the character could have been included as guarding the gates to Gre'thor through [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]. Hines was critical of the parallels between Miral and Janeway, believing certain sequences would have been more effective without Janeway present. Ranking it at number thirteen out of the twenty-two ''Star Trek'' episodes written by Fuller, [[Blastr]]'s Dany Roth praised the writer's attempt to better address Torres as a character, but felt his approach to the afterlife and spirituality were too direct and literal. John Andrews of ''[[Den of Geek!]]'' responded positively to the episode's emphasis on Torres and Klingon mythology, but felt that it was "still pretty hokey".{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/tv/star-trek/258179/every-bryan-fuller-star-trek-episode-ever-ranked|title=Every Bryan Fuller Star Trek Episode Ever, Ranked|date=September 20, 2016|work=[[Den of Geek!]]|publisher=Dennis Publishing|last1=Andrews|first1=John|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519193617/http://www.denofgeek.com/us/tv/star-trek/258179/every-bryan-fuller-star-trek-episode-ever-ranked|archivedate=May 19, 2017 |deadurl=no}} == References == ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Book sources=== {{refbegin|30em}} * {{cite book |last = Adare |first = Sierra S.|title = "Indian" Stereotypes in TV Science Fiction: First Nations' Voices Speak Out |year = 2009 |publisher = University of Texas Press |location = Austin |isbn =978-0-292-70612-5|ref = Adare2009}} * {{cite book |last = Bainbridge|first = William Sims|title = eGods: Faith Versus Fantasy in Computer Gaming |year = 2013 |publisher = Oxford University Press|location = Oxford |isbn =978-0-1999-3581-9|ref = Bainbridge2013}} * {{cite book |last1 = Brooks |first1 = Tim |last2=Marsh |first2=Earle |title =The Complete Directory to Prime Time Network and Cable TV Shows |year = 2009|publisher =Ballantine Books|location = New York |isbn = 978-0-345-49773-4|ref = brooksmarsh2009}} * {{cite book |last1=Grech|first= Victor |chapter= Klingons: A Cultural Pastiche|title=The Ultimate Star Trek and Philosophy: The Search for Socrates |editor-last1 = Decker |editor-first1 = Kevin S. |editor-last2 = Eberl |editor-first2 = Jason T. |year = 2016 |publisher =John Wiley & Sons|location = Hoboken |pages= 71–82 |isbn = 978-1-119-14600-1 |ref = Grech2016}} * {{cite book |last1=Pank|first1= Dylan |last2=Caro |first2=John |chapter= "Haven't you heard? They look like us now!": Realism and Metaphor in the New Battlestar Galactica |title=Channeling the Future: Essays on Science Fiction and Fantasy Television|editor-last1 = Geraghty |editor-first1 = Lincoln|year = 2009|publisher =Scarecrow Press|location = Lanham |pages= 199–216|isbn = 978-0-8108-6675-1 |ref = PankCaro2009}} * {{cite book |last1 = Kraemer |first1 = Ross |last2=Cassidy |first2=William |last3=Schwartz|first3=Susan L. |title =The Religions of Star Trek |year = 2009|publisher =Basic Books|location = New York |isbn = 978-0-8133-4115-6|ref = KraemerCassidySchwartz2009}} * {{cite book |last = Ruditis |first = Paul|title = Star Trek Voyager Companion |year = 2003 |publisher = Simon and Schuster |location = New York |isbn =978-0-7434-1751-8|ref = ruditis2003}} * {{cite book|last=Wenskus|first=Otta|authorlink=Otta Wenskus|chapter='Soft' Science Fiction and Technical Fantasy: The Ancient World in ''Star Trek'', ''Babylon 5'', ''Battlestar Galactica'' and ''Dr Who''|title=A Companion to Ancient Greece and Rome on Screen|editor-last=Pomeroy|editor-first=Arthur J.|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=Haboken|pages=449–66|isbn=978-1-1187-4129-0|year=2017|ref= Wenskus2017}} {{refend}} ==External links== * {{IMDb episode|0708852}} * {{TV.com episode|star-trek-voyager/barge-of-the-dead-10762}} {{Memory Alpha|Barge of the Dead (episode)|"Barge of the Dead"}} {{StarTrek.com link|VOY|108140|"Barge of the Dead"}} {{Star Trek: Voyager episodes|6}} {{Portal bar|Science Fiction|Star Trek|Television|United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barge Of The Dead (Star Trek: Voyager)}} [[Category:1999 American television episodes]] [[Category:Star Trek: Voyager (season 6) episodes]] [[Category:Fiction about the afterlife]] [[Category:Death in fiction]]

revision.comment: Fixing style/layout errors and removed underlinked template
revision.text:
{{prose|date=May 2017}} The term "biological computation" refers, variously, to any of the following:
- the study of the [[computation]]s performed by natural [[biota (ecology)|biota]],<ref>Mitchell, M. (2010) Biological Computation. http://www.santafe.edu/media/workingpapers/10-09-021.pdf</ref><ref>Didales, K. (2007) ''Being - Our New Understanding of the Meaning of Life.'' https://sites.google.com/site/djhbrown2/IPM.pdf</ref><ref>Bray, D. ''Wetware: A Computer in Every Living Cell'' (2009) {{ISBN|0-300-14173-4}}, {{ISBN|978-0-300-14173-3}} </ref><ref>NIMBios (2015) ''Information and entropy in biological systems ''http://www.nimbios.org/workshops/WS_entropy</ref> including the subject matter of [[systems biology]].
- the design of [[algorithm]]s inspired by the computational methods of biota <ref>Lamm, E. and Unger, R. ''Biological Computation''. Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2011.</ref>
- the [[design]] and [[engineering]] of manufactured computational devices using [[synthetic biology]] components<ref>Biological Computation Group at MIT - Psrg.csail.mit.edu {{cite web|url=http://www.psrg.csail.mit.edu/biocomp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030232132/http://www.psrg.csail.mit.edu/biocomp/ |archivedate=2013-10-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>Sergi Regot, Javier Macia, Núria Conde, Kentaro Furukawa, Jimmy Kjellén, Tom Peeters, Stefan Hohmann, Eulàlia de Nadal, Francesc Posas & Ricard Solé (2011) Distributed biological computation with multicellular engineered networks. http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v469/n7329/full/nature09679.html </ref>
- computer methods for the analysis of biological data, elsewhere called [[computational biology]]<ref>Biological Computation - Microsoft Research. http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/groups/biology</ref>
When biological computation refers to using [[biology]] to build [[computer]]s, it is a subfield of [[computer science]] and is distinct from the [[interdisciplinary]] [[science]] of [[bioinformatics]] which simply uses computers to better understand biology.
==Books== *''Biological computation'' (2011) by Ehud Lamm and Ron Unger, CRC Press, {{ISBN|978-1-4200-8796-3}}.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Comp-sci-stub}} [[Category:Computational biology]] [[Category:Computational fields of study]]

'''Brig of Dread''' or '''Bridge of Dread''' is a bridge to [[Purgatory]] that a dead [[Soul (spirit)|soul]] had to cross. [[Evil]] souls fall from the bridge into [[hell]]. This is a common [[afterlife]] theme found in some form or other in many cultures.
The "Brig o' Dread" is an important element in ''The [[Lyke-Wake Dirge]]'', an old Northern English [[Wake (ceremony)|waking]] song.
There is much in that song that seems [[Germanic polytheism|Germanic heathen]]. The "Brig o' Dread" probably being related to [[Bifröst]] (which probably means "trembling-way") or [[Gjallarbrú]] ("resounding-bridge" or "noisy-bridge" <ref>[[Hilda Ellis Davidson|Hilda Roderick Ellis Davidson]] (1964). ''Gods and Myths of Northern Europe''. Penguin Books. p. 231.</ref>) <ref>''The New Encyclopædia Britannica, Part 3, Volume 5'', 1983. p. 533</ref><ref>Wendy Doniger (1999). ''Merriam-Webster's Encyclopedia of World Religions''. Merriam-Webster. {{ISBN|0-87779-044-2}}, {{ISBN|978-0-87779-044-0}}. p. 282.</ref> which may be the symbolism here rather than the Christian later folk-etymological explanation.<ref>[[John Christopher Atkinson]], J. R. Smith (1868). [https://books.google.com/books?id=NPBIAAAAcAAJ ''A Glossary of the Cleveland Dialect: Explanatory, Derivative, and Critica''l]. London: John Russell Smith. p. 601.</ref>
It is also mentioned in ''The Ballad of Judas Iscariot'' by [[Robert Williams Buchanan|Robert Buchanan]].
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Brig Of Dread}} [[Category:Afterlife places]] [[Category:Northumbrian folklore]]
{{Spirituality-stub}}

revision.comment: the work's name is "The New York Times" using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''[[Capital punishment]]''' was abolished in '''[[Suriname]]''' in 2015.
The last execution took place in 1982. By signing the Treaty of San José in 1987, the death penalty had already been abolished ''de facto''.
==History== Since [[Suriname]] was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] colony until 1975, it followed Dutch law, which did not permit capital punishment. From independence in 1975 to 1980, capital punishment was on the books, but no crimes committed were considered severe enough to warrant prosecution for it. From 1980 to 1987, during the period of [[military dictatorship]], the death penalty was used by the military government in the early years of its rule to get rid of political opponents. The last judicial execution in Suriname was that of [[Wilfred Hawker]], a sergeant-major in the Surinamese military who had staged two unsuccessful coup attempts to overthrow the military government. He was executed by firing squad on 13 March 1982. The government did carry out a series of [[extrajudicial execution]]s in December 1982, when 15 imprisoned opponents of the military regime were shot without trial. The events would become known as the [[December murders]].
==Law== The death penalty had already been abolished ''[[de facto]]'' by signing the Treaty of San José in 1987, and in March 2015, the National Assembly approved legislation formally abolishing the death penalty in Suriname. But the legislators raised the highest prison term limits from 30 to 50 years in what is seen as a compromise to amending the Criminal code.
==References== *[[Associated Press]], [https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/14/world/around-the-world-rebel-leader-s-execution-announced-by-suriname.html "Rebel Leader's Execution Announced by Suriname"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', 1982-03-14
==External links== *[[:nl:Doodstraf#Suriname|''Capital punishment in Suriname'']] on the [[Dutch Wikipedia]]. *http://www.jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20150306/suriname-abolishes-death-penalty {{Capital punishment}} {{South America in topic|Capital punishment in}}
[[Category:Capital punishment by country|Suriname]] [[Category:Surinamese law]] [[Category:Death in Suriname]] [[Category:Human rights in Suriname]]

[[File:Le Petit Journal - Chauffeurs.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The ''Chauffeurs de la Drome'' torture a victim, ''[[Le Petit Journal (newspaper)|Le Petit Journal]]'', 15 November 1908]]
A '''chauffeur''', ([[French language|French]], "heater upper") was a type of French criminal active from the 18th to the 20th centuries. In gangs, they carried out [[Home invasion]]s on remote, rural dwellings, then tortured the householders into revealing the hiding places of savings or valuables. This was often done by burning victims' feet in the fireplace, which gave rise to the name for them.
A notable gang was the [[Chauffeurs de la Drome]] who were responsible for eighteen murders between 1905 and 1908.<ref name="Anderson2011">{{cite book|author=Malcolm Anderson|title=In Thrall to Political Change: Police and Gendarmerie in France|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CYqKByxmueEC&pg=PA53|date=25 August 2011|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-969364-1|pages=53}}</ref>
These attacks continued after the Second World War. ''Le gang des Romanis'' was active in [[Bourgogne]] and ''Le Gang d’Albert'' was active in [[Picardy]] until their leaders were separately captured and executed in 1952.<ref name="BAUER2013">{{cite book|author=Alain BAUER|title=Dictionnaire amoureux du Crime|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wJ6hqz3ZVJoC&pg=PT107|date=21 February 2013|publisher=edi8|isbn=978-2-259-22072-9|pages=104–107}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Violent crime]] [[Category:Crime in France]]

{|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Ming class SS.svg |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=China |Ship flag=[[Image:Naval Ensign of the People's Republic of China.svg|60px|Chinese (PRC) Navy Ensign]] |Ship name=''No. 361'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate= |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass2-|Ming|submarine}} |Ship displacement=*{{convert|1584|t|LT|lk=out}} surfaced *{{convert|2113|t|LT}} submerged |Ship length={{convert|76|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|7.6|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= {{convert|5.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=*2 × Shaanxi 6E 390 ZC1 diesels rated at 5,200 hp (3.82 MW) *2 × Xiangtan alternators *2 shafts |Ship speed=*{{convert|15|kn|km/h|lk=in}} surfaced *{{convert|18|kn|km/h}} submerged |Ship range= |Ship complement=55 (9 officers) |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*6 × bow torpedo tubes *2 × stern torpedo tubes |Ship notes= }} |} The submarine hull number '''No. 361''' named ''[[Great Wall|The Great Wall]] #61'' (长城61号) was a Chinese [[People's Liberation Army Navy]] Type-035AIP (ES5E variant) (NATO reporting name [[Ming class|Ming III]]) conventional diesel/electric [[submarine]]. In April 2003, during an exercise in the [[Yellow Sea]] between [[North Korea]] and China's [[Shandong]] Province, the vessel suffered a mechanical failure that killed all 70 crew members on board.<ref name=dtic/><ref name=youji/> It was one of China's worst peacetime military disasters. The PLA Navy's Commander [[Shi Yunsheng]] and Political Commissar [[Yang Huaiqing]] were both dismissed as a result of the accident.<ref name="dtic" />
==Background== {{main|Type 035 submarine}} No. 361 was part of the 12th Brigade of the [[North Sea Fleet]] of the PLAN based at [[Lüshunkou]] (formerly Port Arthur) in [[Liaoning]] Province. It was a Type-035AIP (Ming class) submarine.{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
According to CNN, China was increasing training and exercises of its submarines in the east to carry out a policy of "sea denial" to counter the powerful U.S. Pacific fleet.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/asiapcf/east/05/02/china.submarine China says sub disaster killed 70]</ref>
==Fatal incident== According to the official Chinese news agency [[Xinhua]], all 70 crew members died when the submarine's diesel engine used up all the oxygen (because it failed to shut down properly) while the boat was submerged on April 16, 2003. The submarine, which was commanded by [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] Cheng Fuming (程福明), had been taking part in naval exercises east of Inner [[Changshan Islands]] in the Yellow Sea off the coast of Northeastern China. Along with its normal complement, the crew also included 13 trainee cadets from the Chinese naval academy.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2003-07/02/content_936853.htm |title=Foreign Ministry Spokesperson's Press Conference on May 8, 2003 |access-date=2005-09-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060308055609/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2003-07/02/content_936853.htm |archive-date=2006-03-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
At a press conference on May 8, 2003, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Zhang Qiyue stated that while on an exercise east of Changshan Islands, the No. 361 submarine was lost due to a mechanical problem and all 70 onboard perished. The submarine had been towed to a port as of the time of the press conference.<ref>{{Cite press release |title=2003年5月8日外交部发言人在记者招待会上答记者问 |date=2003-05-08 |publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China]] |url=http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/web//fyrbt_673021/dhdw_673027/t24552.shtml |access-date=2018-05-07}}</ref>
After the disaster, the crippled submarine drifted for ten days because it was on a silent, no-contact exercise. The boat was discovered by Chinese fishermen who noticed its periscope sticking above the surface on April 25, 2003. The submarine was initially towed to Yulin Harbor near [[Sanya]] on [[Hainan]] Island before being taken back to the northeast seaport of [[Dalian]] in [[Liaoning]] province.
==Aftermath== On May 2, 2003, Central Military Commission chairman [[Jiang Zemin]] said in a condolence message to the families of the dead that "the officers and sailors of 361 remembered their sacred duty entrusted to them by the Party and the people. They died on duty, sacrificed themselves for the country, and they are great losses to the People’s Navy."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.people.com.cn/GB/shizheng/16/20030502/983786.html |title=我海军一潜艇失事 70官兵遇难 江泽民发唁电 |access-date=2018-05-07 |agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |editor-last=Song |editor-first=Liyun |location=Beijing |publication-date=2003-05-02 |trans-title=A Navy submarine suffered accident, all 70 onboard lost, Jiang Zemin sent condolence.}}</ref>
CMC Vice-chairman [[Guo Boxiong]] led an enquiry into the incident, which resulted in the dismissal or demotion of five senior PLAN officers in June 2013: Navy Commander [[Shi Yunsheng]] (replaced by [[Zhang Dingfa]]) and Political Commissar [[Yang Huaiqing]]; North Sea Fleet Commander [[Ding Yiping]], Political Commissar Chen Xianfeng (陈先锋), and Chief of Staff Xiao Xinnian.<ref name=dtic>{{cite web |url=http://www.dtic.mil/docs/citations/ADA591531 |title=Behind the Periscope: Leadership in China's Navy |author1=Becker, Jeffrey |author2=Liebenberg, David |author3=Mackenzie, Peter |date=December 2013 |publisher=[[Defense Technical Information Center]] |page=81}}</ref> Ding Yiping had been groomed to be the candidate for Navy Commander, but was removed from contention after the accident. Admiral [[Wu Shengli]] eventually succeeded Zhang Dingfa as Commander.<ref name=youji>{{cite book |author=You Ji |chapter=Meeting the Challenge of the Upcoming PLAAF Leadership Reshuffle |title=The Chinese Air Force: Evolving Concepts, Roles, and Capabilities |url=http://ndupress.ndu.edu/Portals/68/Documents/Books/chinese-air-force.pdf |year=2012 |publisher=[[National Defense University Press]] |isbn=978-0-16-091386-0 |page=231}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sinodefence.com/navy/sub/035.asp Type 035 (Ming Class) Diesel-Electric Submarine] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051028152251/http://taiwansecurity.org/WP/2003/WP-050303.htm Chinese Submarine Accident Kills 70] (Taiwanese Security Research) * [http://www.afcea.org/signal/articles/anmviewer.asp?a=93&z=22 includes a picture of 361] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/2999533.stm China sub deaths 'must rouse Navy'] (BBC News) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/2987954.stm Sackings after China's sub disaster] (BBC News) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/3001099.stm China sub victims 'suffocated'] (BBC News) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/2998717.stm HK press seeks answers to sub accident] (BBC News) * [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/china/images/ch_ming_012_an-361.jpg Picture of Submarine 361]
{{2003 shipwrecks}}
